messageBody:
That's an interesting idea. I never thought of using JUnit in my production
code to do DbC.

One feature of other DbC implementations is the ability to turn off checks
at runtime -- is this possible with JUnit? I don't think it is, but it
seems like it would be pretty simple to add.

My impression is that DbC checks are usually turned off when the code is
shipped, but I don't have much experience with DbC. Someone else with more
knowledge may be able to enlighten me.

Matt

From: kentlbeck [mailto:kentbeck@...]
Sent: Friday, April 26, 2002 12:39 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: Changing junit.framework.Assert to instance methods


--- In junit@y..., "dvydra2" <david@v...> wrote:
> I needed to make Assert.fail(...) an instance method so I could
> override it and allow for multiple failures.
> http://sourceforge.net/projects/jfunc took the same approach.

When I've wished for multiple failures to be recorded in my tests, my
tests were always too big. Splitting up the tests gave me more
satisfactory tests, and pinpointed errors.

If you want multiple failures, it sounds like you want a different
mechanism than fail().

The advantage of having the methods be static is that you can do DbC
and have pre-/post-condition failures reported like all other JUnit
failures.

Kent
